The game is great. Don't get me wrong. But I have a few issues:

[h2]Achievements Locked Behind Payed DLC's[/h2]

But as an achievement hunter... Someone trying to complete more of the backlog to ensure that I play through my games and experience everything the game has to offer before putting it down...

[b]Putting achievements behind DLC paywalls is [u]disgusting[/u] and honestly ruins the feel of the game.[/b] This scheme turns the game from a relaxed, chill, satisfaction based game about power washing into something that makes you not want to play anymore.

[h2]Achievements are "Do things in order" and not "Accomplish the difficult task."[/h2]

Many of the achievements are not "100% this map without using a ladder" or "100% this map without using this attachment". The achievements are "Clean this thing before cleaning that thing." That's not an achievement. Nothing has been accomplished. Nobody is going "Yay! I cleaned the things in order!" But now imagine: Completing a map by using no equipment and having to climb your way around the environment to get to certain angles. You're essentially turning the map into a jumping puzzle on top of the cleaning. [b]THAT[/b] is something that anybody can be proud of accomplishing.

Overall the game is good and satisfying. But with these glaring issues, I can't in good faith, push myself to 100% this game.

Edit: Formatting

I normally wait until a game is perfected to review it, and I did actually in fact have this game perfected at one point, until the addition of DLC.
I have no problem with DLC's until you lock achievements behind paywalls, forcing someone to dish out money if they want to perfect to game, and thus, making the game P2W, which I don't support.

I played the campaign "Career Mode" to completion and I have issues with the game.

The game is marketed as a relaxing and satisfying cleaning sim. However, there are a few quirks that make it anything but.

The game starts out simple enough and the satisfaction is there. As the game progresses it becomes increasingly more challenging and less satisfying than when you first started your journey. I was hoping for more of a sim style game where you grow a business, but all you do is clean more absurd objects as the story unfolds.

Because there is no depth to the game and all you do is clean ad nauseam I would have expected the cleaning experience to be more polished or thought out. It ends up just being a fight with the developers who put you in precarious positions almost mocking you "Let's see if they can find this spot to clean!"

Do not let the hype of positive reviews or the appeal of the game play videos entice you if you just want a relaxing power wash sim. It was not relaxing and far from satisfying. I only played to the end out of spite for spending money on this game. 

-  Soap is a niche tool that can often make cleaning an area more challenging rather than easier. (Note: this is a LIMITED resource, you can buy out the shop to zero with intermittent restocks. Are you kidding me!)

-Surface area calculations are inconsistent leaving you hunting for odd spots and areas to clean to obtain 100% clean

-Objects are placed in weird spots making the act of cleaning frustrating instead of fun

-No depth to career mode. Just keep cleaning and then it ends. Would have liked to see building a business game play here.

[h2]Achievements Locked Behind Payed DLC's[/h2]

But as an achievement hunter... Someone trying to complete more of the backlog to ensure that I play through my games and experience everything the game has to offer before putting it down...

[b]Putting achievements behind DLC paywalls is [u]disgusting[/u] and honestly ruins the feel of the game.[/b] This scheme turns the game from a relaxed, chill, satisfaction based game about power washing into something that makes you not want to play anymore.

[h2]Achievements are "Do things in order" and not "Accomplish the difficult task."[/h2]

Many of the achievements are not "100% this map without using a ladder" or "100% this map without using this attachment". The achievements are "Clean this thing before cleaning that thing." That's not an achievement. Nothing has been accomplished. Nobody is going "Yay! I cleaned the things in order!" But now imagine: Completing a map by using no equipment and having to climb your way around the environment to get to certain angles. You're essentially turning the map into a jumping puzzle on top of the cleaning. [b]THAT[/b] is something that anybody can be proud of accomplishing.

Overall the game is good and satisfying. But with these glaring issues, I can't in good faith, push myself to 100% this game.

Edit: Formatting

I normally wait until a game is perfected to review it, and I did actually in fact have this game perfected at one point, until the addition of DLC.
I have no problem with DLC's until you lock achievements behind paywalls, forcing someone to dish out money if they want to perfect to game, and thus, making the game P2W, which I don't support.
Which is a huge shame as I thoroughly enjoyed the base game, but forcing the user to buy DLC's in order to access achievements is scummy, and I can't recommend this game because of it,

[h1]The real life version is more fun than this game and that's sad[/h1]

Seeing some simulator games like PowerWash Simulator, you're intrigued. The real world version of this isn't very fun, how did they manage to make it fun in the game? While many simulator games excel at this, turning everyday chores into fun games, [b]PowerWash fails at it.[/b]

[b]Throughout the entire time I played this, not one drop of Dopamine was secreted by my brain.[/b]


You just point at acres of stains and swirl your mouse left and right to clean it up. That's it. Your powewash has different nozzles that changes how wide water is sprayed. 0 degree nozzle for a line that is powerful, up to 40 degree nozzle which sprays a bigger surface area but is the weakest. All of this means that you have to change nozzle every now and then to get rid of tough stains or focus more on light but big grimes. In game, all of this can be summed up with one word: [b]Boring.[/b]


You have the option to use a soap dispenser which can clean easier and a bigger area, but it's just an option you can spend money on and not really get your money's worth. It's not like some stains [b]require[/b] soap or other liquids. No, they're all washed the same way. You can just decide to waste money on soap to [b]TRY [/b]and get some variation into gameplay, but seeing as how they run out in 10 seconds, it offers nothing.


Compared to some simulator games like [b]Viscera Cleanup Detail[/b] (a successful cleanup game) there are no gimmicks or management.[list]
[*] In Viscera you had to fill, empty and move around buckets of water which you would use to cleanup your mop. Knocking them over would cause a spill, messing up your work. Stepping in said mess (or any other puddle) would cause you to leave footprints. So it would create a minigame where you would try to efficiently manage your buckets.
[*]  You had body parts with physics to collect into a crate and incinerate. Said body parts could wiggle and slap at walls during movement, covering them in blood. More management minigame.
[*]  When removing bullet holes from surfaces you'd use the Laser Welder which could overheat and start fire, implementing another mini-game into the gameplay.
[/list]

PowerWash Simulator has [b]NOTHING[/b]! No water limit or management, no hose management, there is literally nothing to do in this game but look at walls and spray like a robot. Because Viscera had so many minigames to manage, it wouldn't cover the entire map in stains to clean. It would try keep it moderated, but because PowerWash has [b]NOTHING[/b], all it can do is cover [u][b]every single bit of surface[/b][/u] in dirt and grime in an attempt to make its level's fun, which it fails at miserably because it does the actual opposite.

 
Even the locations themselves are boring. Viscera had sci-fi space stations with puzzles to solve and even areas based on pop culture, like The Thing movie. PowerWash has you cleaning boring, everyday objects that you could see just by sticking your head out your room's window.


How do you know how much progress you've made in the map? On the top left corner there is a percentage of how much is left. You can spend 40 minutes getting to 98% and then spend a whole 10 minutes for that last 2%. Why? Because [b]the game has no proper way of guiding you to the last bits[/b]. When you're cleaning a whole garden that has more nook and cranny than a ant's nest, [b]at the last 2% you're scouring the entire map[/b], looking under every rock to find a coin-sized stain to remove.
The game [b]TRIES[/b] to make it easy by telling you what the last 3 uncleaned items are, but it's a joke. Before the 3 items, you're on your own and when you get to the 3 items, it tells you 1 fence post is uncleaned, while the map contains 8. Yes, I had to inspect all 8, not find the stain and ultimately hose down all 8 again to get a hidden stain removed. F*ck me!


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I've washed a whole balcony with a power wash in real life and despite the machine requiring rest every now and then and my hands getting numb, [b]it was still more fun than this piece of crap[/b].
There is not a single saving grace in this game and [b]I would not recommend it, ever, even if it was free.[/b]

I played the campaign "Career Mode" to completion and I have issues with the game.

The game is marketed as a relaxing and satisfying cleaning sim. However, there are a few quirks that make it anything but.

The game starts out simple enough and the satisfaction is there. As the game progresses it becomes increasingly more challenging and less satisfying than when you first started your journey. I was hoping for more of a sim style game where you grow a business, but all you do is clean more absurd objects as the story unfolds.

Because there is no depth to the game and all you do is clean ad nauseam I would have expected the cleaning experience to be more polished or thought out. It ends up just being a fight with the developers who put you in precarious positions almost mocking you "Let's see if they can find this spot to clean!"

Do not let the hype of positive reviews or the appeal of the game play videos entice you if you just want a relaxing power wash sim. It was not relaxing and far from satisfying. I only played to the end out of spite for spending money on this game. 

-  Soap is a niche tool that can often make cleaning an area more challenging rather than easier. (Note: this is a LIMITED resource, you can buy out the shop to zero with intermittent restocks. Are you kidding me!)

-Surface area calculations are inconsistent leaving you hunting for odd spots and areas to clean to obtain 100% clean

-Objects are placed in weird spots making the act of cleaning frustrating instead of fun

-No depth to career mode. Just keep cleaning and then it ends. Would have liked to see building a business game play here.

-Equipment is one dimensional. Just 4 cleaning gun types (with progressively better stats) and same attachments that you have to keep re-purchasing over and over again for all the cleaning guns.
